alert.note: Alert for Polk (Tennessee) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 1:47PM CST until January 10 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Knoxville
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Morristown TN has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Georgia...Tennessee... Toccoa/Ocoee River Above Copperhill TN affecting Polk and Fannin Counties. For the Ocoee River...including Copperhill TN, OCOEE DAM #1 PARKSVILLE...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Toccoa/Ocoee River above Copperhill TN. * WHEN...Until tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 6.0 feet, Bankfull conditions are reached along the river upstream and downstream from the gage off of Tennessee Highway 68 or Ocoee Street in west Copperhill Tennessee. This includes low lying portions of the Horsebend Park in McCaysville Georgia. At 8.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding begins of woodlands, fields and backyards of homes near the river upstream and downstream from the gage off Tennessee Highway 68 or Ocoee Street in Copperhill Tennessee. The rock access road to the gage will begin to flood. Flooding begins in the backyards of homes and the Horsebend Park in McCaysville Georgia. At 10.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into woodlands, fields, and backyards of homes near the river. The rock access road to the gage will be under two feet of water. Portions of parking lots near the river will begin to flood behind the Copperhill Tennessee Post Office and other businesses along Ocoee Street. Also flooding expands into the backyards of homes and the Horsebend Park in McCaysville Georgia. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 7.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate above flood stage with a maximum value of 8.5 feet this evening. It will fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 600 AM EST.
